awd_titl_txt: CNH-S: RUI: Understanding the effective processes by which communities manage tropical forests
awd_abstract_narration:
This interdisciplinary research project will evaluate the effective management of tropical forests by communities. The project will draw on and contribute to understandings of the ways that individuals, groups, and organizations collectively manage forests and other resources in the face of increasing population and changes in land-use and environmental conditions.  The project will provide new insights regarding the ways effective community interactions, including communication and knowledge sharing between stakeholder groups, and strong forms of leadership can build trust and enhance the capacity of communities to undertake effective community-based land management.  Project results will provide new perspectives regarding the mechanisms through which communities can effectively manage forests.  The project also will provide valuable education and training opportunities for undergraduate students at a small liberal arts college as well as enhancement of international collaborative links.

The investigators will conduct a focused case study of 45 sites where the cultural significance of the site leads to shadow conservation.  They will measure the changes in forest size, shape and crown closure over the last 50 years and assess the present ecological status of the forests.  They will determine the elements of social cohesion that impact forest use and valuation, and they will assess how the ecological status of the forests affects social cohesion and societal customs such as religious practice.  They also will determine which management strategies are most effective at maintaining healthy forest ecological status.  Project findings will provide new insights and information that will contribute to a broad line of inquiry and the insights generated by this project will have practical value for community-based management of forests and other landscapes in the U.S. and elsewhere.  This project is supported by the NSF Dynamics of Coupled Natural and Human Systems (CNH) Program.

por.por_cntn:
Socioeconomic and political pressures are increasing deforestation worldwide. Remarkably, a network of shadow conservation sites (accidental conservation sites such as sacred forests) has resisted these pressures through the cultural, religious, and social significance of their forests. The major goals of our project were to determine the effectiveness of religious management on sacred church forest ecological status and, in turn, the importance of forest status on social cohesion in sacred forests. Our model system was Ethiopian church forests that are part of the dominant religion in Ethiopia, Christian Orthodox Tewahido Church (EOTC). These church forests are small, on average 5.2 hectares (range 1.7 - 148.9 ha), but many, with ~1022 of these forests surrounding churches in  the South Gondar Region (14,607 km2) of northern Ethiopia. Although small, these forests are valuable because they are biodiversity hotspots of endangered and endemic taxa as they are the only forests in the region; provide essential ecosystem services to the surrounding community such as space to gather and shade; and are significant to the local community. These are not static sites, but culturally and religiously rich gathering areas that are part of a complex and dynamic socio-ecological system that is central to local communities and critical for the ecosystem services they provide. 

Our ecological and landscape analyses of these forests found that they have high human disturbance from plantations, clearings, and buildings, but are persistent and resilient across the landscape. Only 4 church forests have disappeared across the landscape over the past 90 years, but crown closure has declined over this same time period and the forest cover in the matrix surrounding the forests has declined by 4x of what it was, which exposes these forests to greater edge effects, threatening their integrity and regeneration capacity. We found variation in ecological status across forests including species diversity, regeneration potential, and soil health. To determine the relationship community members have with their local forests as well as to determine the variation in forest use, we conducted in-depth interviews with key stakeholders as well as conducted surveys of local communities members across 20 forests. We found consistent community use of forest resources with variation in access to state benefits such as land access and agricultural extension efforts; key forest protection norms such as educators about forest protection, and who respondents feel is responsible for forest protection; and individual factors such as age and indicators of wealth. 

While the degree of human presence negatively impacts plant species richness, forest biomass, forest regeneration, and selects for weedy, exotic, and wind-dispersed species, these sacred church forests exist because of the humans that use the forests as both religious and social spaces. The forests themselves are not seen as sacred but they protect the church and the divine. Thus, the forest exists largely because of an informal indigenous protection system based on the community’s shared religious values and traditions, not because of a land stewardship ethic that prioritizes the preservation of biodiversity and forest cover. Building on this work, we are currently examining how the social and ecological systems are linked. We aim to (i) understand the relationship between social variation and ecological health of these forests and (ii) evaluate the predictive value of social, ecological and socioecological models to predict positive ecological outcomes. Our integrative methods to identify the main factors that vary within these religious communities, and how these affect forest management, can be applied  in other community-based conservation systems for a targeted conservation and management approach.

 

Broader Impacts

This research project has impacts across scales. This research has formed the basis for 6 US-based undergraduate theses and is the focus of 1 PhD candidate. Nine of our 12 collaborative publications include undergraduate, graduate, or postdoctoral students. Of those 6 US-based undergraduate students (5 women, 2 underrepresented), 4 have gone onto masters or Ph.D. programs in biology. It also helped train 13 undergraduate students in interdisciplinary research in both the field and in the laboratory. Internationally, this research was made possible by, and supported collaborations with, two Professors at Bahir Dar University, Ethiopia, including the promotion of 1 and trained 3 graduate students (2 masters (1 woman) and 1 PhD student). The legacy of these collaborations is in continued research on the conservation of these threatened and biodiverse forests. Among the research group, this project has supported the advancement of all of the PI’s in promotional advancement in the US (2 women, 1 underrepresented).

Our research has increased awareness of the importance of religious management through two principal mechanisms:  scientific articles and local collaborations. Our local interactions included repeated trips and collaborations with faculty, engagement with community members including key stakeholders such as priests, and collaboration with the agricultural office.
